name: ATM Jackpotting DFIR 2025
description: MITRE ATT&CK layer for ATM jackpotting incident investigated by Thai Cyber Police, 2025. Based on reported techniques involving physical access, malware (e.g., Ploutus.D), and black-box devices.

techniques.comment: Attackers may exploit vulnerabilities in ATM software or network interfaces remotely, as seen in some jackpotting cases (e.g., Diebold Nixdorf attacks).
Phishing emails used to compromise bank networks, enabling remote ATM access (e.g., Cosmos heist).
Malware like Ploutus.D or Tyupkin uses command-line interfaces or scripts to issue cash dispense commands via ATM pin pad or software.
Malware may modify ATM boot processes for persistence, though specific evidence in Thai case is unclear.
Attackers switch ATMs to supervisor mode to gain control over cash dispensers, a common jackpotting technique.
Attackers remove evidence by disconnecting black-box devices or clearing logs to avoid detection.
Use of mineral oil or wax to block ATM cameras or tampering with logs to hide attack activities.
Malware may collect transaction logs or cardholder data, though primary goal is cash dispensing.
Black-box devices communicate with attackersâ€™ smartphones or servers to control ATM cash dispensers remotely.
Malware may corrupt ATM logs or software to cover tracks, though not explicitly reported in Thai case.
ATMs display 'Out of Service' to avoid suspicion during jackpotting attacks.
